text: If an item may not exist in a list, can we still do if-else to check condition?

code:
mystr = 'hello.py'
mystr = 'hello'
if not 'py' in mystr.rsplit('.')[1]:

text: The first case is fine, but the second case results in an "out of range" error.
If .py exists in the string, do nothing.
If .py is not part of the filename, do XYZ.
Note : The user input may or may not have a .
Either check the length, or convert the list into a string.
I am not sure if this is too localized.
